content.webTitle: Highs and lows in the life of Thabo Mbeki

fields.headline: Highs and lows in the life of Thabo Mbeki
fields.bodyText: 1956 Aged 14, the young Thabo Mbeki follows his father - Gorvan, an ANC stalwart and Communist party member - by joining the African National Congress Youth League. 1970 He travels to Soviet Union for political and military training. 1971 Returns to Africa and joins the ANC exiled in Zambian capital Lusaka 1975 Appointed to ANC national executive. 1986 The South African government dispatches an assassin to Zambia to bomb his house. 1989 Appointed head of the ANC department of international affairs, Mbeki speaks to Nelson Mandela by phone for the first time since his arrest in 1960. Leads an ANC delegation in secret talks with the government, which lead to the ANC giving up its armed struggle. 1990 Officially returns to South Africa on 27 April after the ANC is unbanned. 1993 Elected chairman of the ANC. 1994 Sworn in on 10 May as Deputy President in the ANC government. 1996 Sacks Winnie Mandela from her deputy ministerial job for abuse of privileges. 1997 Elected President of the ANC . 1999 Elected President of South Africa 2000 Mbeki writes an open letter to world leaders in which he makes clear his belief that HIV does not cause Aids, causing an outcry in the medical and international community. 2004 Elected to a second term as President of South Africa. 2007 Loses a bitter ANC leadership election against Jacob Zuma. 2008 Mbeki attempts to mediate in negotiations between Zimbabwe's MDC party and Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF. After the throwing out of corruption charges against his political rival Jacob Zuma and allegations of his interference in the process, Mbeki announces yesterday that he will accept a call to resign from the governing ANC.
